comments.author: jschanck
comments.body: I would avoid defining the CPA PKE at all in this document. Specifically, I would inline `CPAPKE_KeyGen` and `CPAPKE_Dec` into `KeyGen` and `Dec`. I would then rename `CPAPKE_Enc` to something like `InnerEnc` and describe it as a helper function for code that is shared between `Enc` and `Dec`.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
It is very hard to ensure data-independent constant-time operations in Python. It can be done, but it will make the specification less readable. To begin, we can't use the plain `int` type.

My preference is not to bother with it in `kyber.py`: if we'd use a `cmov` then we would be suggesting that the rest is constant-time as well, which it most definitely is not.

comments.author: jschanck
comments.body:
Yeah I wouldn't expect it to be constant time in python. My issue is that
```python
    if ct == ct2: # NOTE <- in production this must be done in constant time!
        return KDF(Kbar2 + H(ct))
    return KDF(z + H(ct))
```
only says that the comparison must be constant time. An implementer might skip the computation of `KDF(Kbar2 + H(ct))` when the branch is not taken. (The wording in the spec is fine.) 

So I would write something like
```python
    return constant_time_select(ct, ct2, KDF(Kbar2 + H(ct)), KDF(z + H(ct)))

def constant_time_select(a, b, x, y):
    # WARNING! This implementation is insecure.
    # Examples of safer implementations in several languages can be found in [XXX].
    return x if a == b else y
```

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: I like your suggestion.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: Still needs a reference.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
There are two reasons why I like having the seeds explicit:

1. First, it makes it easy to use kyber.py to test other implementations. In the end, it's a specification, not an implementation.

2. If KEMTLS gets traction, it's convenient to be able to store the short seed instead of the full private key.
Why do you prefer the randombytes() style?

(Note that the explicit seeds are used both in kyber.py and the specification itself.)

comments.author: jschanck
comments.body:
> having the seeds explicit [...] makes it easy to use kyber.py to test other implementations.

Other implementations are likely to use NIST's API, which will not use explicit seeds. So I'm not sure I see a benefit.

All implementations are likely to test against the NIST KATs. So they will need to know how various values of "seed" are related to the `RandomBytes` calls in NIST's standard. The current spec does not make that obvious. E.g. the phrasing
>    Split seed into 2.
>       - A 32-octet cpaSeed
>       - A 32-octet z

obscures the fact that `seed` must be the concatenation of two sequential `RandomBytes(32)` calls for the purpose of checking the KATs.

>  Why do you prefer the randombytes() style?

There's a risk that explicit seeds will be misused. We can add warnings to the text (which readers might miss...), or we can simply write `RandomBytes(32)` when we mean 32 random bytes. After all, it's a spec, not an implementation ;).

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
> Other implementations are likely to use NIST's API

Those that copy the C reference definitely, but the NIST API is very unnatural. In Go, for instance, the idiomatic equivalent would be to pass a `rand io.Reader` parameter which can't emulate the annoying behaviour that RandomBytes(32) + RandomBytes(32) ≠ RandomBytes(64).

> obscures the fact that seed must be the concatenation of two sequential RandomBytes(32) calls for the purpose of checking the KATs.

That this distinction exists is an argument against using the NIST randombytes API. I think it's better to make checking against the NIST test vectors a bit more difficult. We can also have a separate set of test vectors which are easier to check against (and are tailored with specific corner-cases as far as they exist.)

> There's a risk that explicit seeds will be misused. 

People will use deterministic key generation, which is inconvenient with a RandomBytes style API. I admit I don't see a good reason to pass the seed to encapsulation.
